verses.text: Then Moses answered and said, 'But look, they will not believe me or listen to my voice; for they will say, “The LORD has not appeared to you.”'
verses.comment: Moses anticipates Israel’s disbelief; stays close to the Hebrew structure.

verses.text: And the LORD said to him, 'What is that in your hand?' And he said, 'A staff.'
verses.comment: Word-for-word translation; 'staff' for 'מַטֶּה' (matteh).

verses.text: And He said, 'Throw it on the ground.' So he threw it on the ground, and it became a snake, and Moses ran from it.
verses.comment: Used ‘snake’ as standard modern equivalent for ‘nahash’.

verses.text: But the LORD said to Moses, 'Put out your hand and catch it by the tail.' So he put out his hand and caught it, and it became a staff in his hand.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; 'catch it by the tail' is a direct translation.

verses.text: 'That they may believe that the LORD, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.'
verses.comment: Reference to patriarchs kept; matches structure of Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: And the LORD said to him further, 'Now put your hand inside your cloak.' And he put his hand inside his cloak, and when he took it out, his hand was leprous, like snow.
verses.comment: Maintained ‘leprous, like snow’ as a literal rendering.

verses.text: And He said, 'Put your hand back inside your cloak.' So he put his hand back inside his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored like the rest of his flesh.
verses.comment: ‘Restored’ mirrors Hebrew verb; ‘like the rest of his flesh’ is direct.

verses.text: 'If they will not believe you or listen to the first sign, they may believe the latter sign.'
verses.comment: ‘Latter sign’ is a formal, literal term for the second miracle.

verses.text: 'But if they will not believe even these two signs or listen to your voice, you shall take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry ground, and the water that you take from the Nile will become blood on the dry ground.'
verses.comment: Poetic structure preserved; ‘become blood’ as per Hebrew.

verses.text: Then Moses said to the LORD, 'Please, O Lord, I am not eloquent, neither before nor since you have spoken to your servant; but I am slow of speech and slow of tongue.'
verses.comment: ‘Slow of speech’ and ‘slow of tongue’ reflect idiomatic Hebrew.

verses.text: And the LORD said to him, 'Who made man’s mouth? Or who makes him mute, or deaf, or seeing, or blind? Is it not I, the LORD?'
verses.comment: Direct, word-for-word rendering.

verses.text: Now go, and I will be with your mouth and teach you what you shall speak.
verses.comment: ‘Be with your mouth’ mirrors idiom in Hebrew.

verses.text: But he said, 'Oh, my Lord, please send someone else.'
verses.comment: ‘Please send someone else’ is a literal idiomatic phrase.

verses.text: Then the anger of the LORD was kindled against Moses, and He said, 'Is there not Aaron, your brother, the Levite? I know that he can speak well. And look, he is coming out to meet you, and when he sees you he will be glad in his heart.'
verses.comment: ‘Anger... was kindled’ is a typical Hebrew idiom for anger.

verses.text: You shall speak to him and put the words in his mouth. I will be with your mouth and with his mouth, and will teach you both what you shall do.
verses.comment: Repetitive, to match Hebrew parallelism.

verses.text: He shall be your spokesman to the people, and you shall be as God to him.
verses.comment: Kept 'as God to him' as direct translation, no paraphrase.

verses.text: And you shall take in your hand this staff, with which you shall perform the signs.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; ‘signs’ is plural as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So Moses went back to Jethro his father-in-law and said to him, 'Please let me go back to my brothers in Egypt to see whether they are still alive.' And Jethro said to Moses, 'Go in peace.'
verses.comment: Kept ‘brothers’ as literal; Jethro used as in Hebrew.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses in Midian, 'Go back to Egypt, for all the men who were seeking your life are dead.'
verses.comment: Phrase matches exact meaning and prophecy cited in Matthew.

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and his sons and set them on a donkey, and went back to the land of Egypt. And Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.comment: ‘Staff of God’ is direct term in Hebrew.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, 'When you go back to Egypt, see that you do all those wonders before Pharaoh which I have put in your hand. But I will harden his heart, so that he will not let the people go.'
verses.comment: 'Harden his heart' is consistent with the literal Hebrew.

verses.text: Then you shall say to Pharaoh, ‘This is what the LORD says: Israel is my firstborn son.’
verses.comment: 'Firstborn son' matches wording in MT and NT quotations.

verses.text: 'And I say to you, let my son go, that he may serve me. But if you refuse to let him go, behold, I will kill your firstborn son.'
verses.comment: ‘Serve me’ reflects the Hebrew ‘עבד’ (avad).

verses.text: At a lodging place on the way, the LORD met him and sought to put him to death.
verses.comment: 'Sought to put him to death' matches text, ambiguous as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Then Zipporah took a flint and cut off her son’s foreskin, and touched his feet with it and said, 'Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me!'
verses.comment: 'Bridegroom of blood' preserved literally; see scholarly debate on meaning.

verses.text: So He let him alone. Then she said, 'A bridegroom of blood,' because of the circumcision.
verses.comment: Phrase matches ambiguity and brevity of Hebrew text.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Aaron, 'Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.' So he went and met him at the mountain of God and kissed him.
verses.comment: 'Mountain of God' for Horeb as in Exodus 3:1.

verses.text: And Moses told Aaron all the words of the LORD with which He had sent him, and all the signs that He had commanded him.
verses.comment: ‘Words’ and ‘signs’ mirror Hebrew.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went and gathered together all the elders of the people of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Elders of the people’ as a set phrase.

verses.text: And Aaron spoke all the words that the LORD had spoken to Moses and performed the signs in the sight of the people.
verses.comment: ‘Performed the signs’ per Hebrew order.

verses.text: And the people believed; and when they heard that the LORD had visited the people of Israel and that He had seen their affliction, they bowed down and worshiped.
verses.comment: ‘Visited’ as Hebrew ‘paqad’ (to attend to); included ‘bowed down and worshiped’ as literal Hebrew sequence.
